1895-09-15 00:10:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: 3 coins
    Active player

      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • 3 coins
      Context for action selection and components
    scoring function

      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Scene 8 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
      Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
      Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
      Context for action selection and components

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he snuck into the local market, his pockets jingling with a few coins he'd pilfered from his mother's purse. He bartered with the fruit vendor, haggling over the price of a basket of apples with a seriousness that belied his age, relishing the feeling of control he held over the transaction.

He meticulously arranged the fruit, crafting a display that would entice even the most frugal customer. He sold out his entire stock by nightfall, his heart swelling with pride at the clinking coins in his pocket.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he returned home from a fruitless trip to the market, his wagon empty and his spirit deflated. He had misjudged the demand for plums, his carefully calculated plan backfiring spectacularly. He retreated to his room, the sting of failure burning in his chest, vowing to never again underestimate the fickle whims of the marketplace.

1895-09-16 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
      Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
      Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
    Active player

      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.

          [13 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market.           [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take a cart of apples to the neighboring town to sell. He meticulously arranged the fruit, crafting a display that would entice even the most frugal customer. He sold out his entire stock by nightfall, his heart swelling with pride at the clinking coins in his pocket.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Scene 10 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
      Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
      Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.

He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 2 coins
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [16 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Cedric Meadowbrook stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook is a fruit vendor in Fruitville who tries to sell fruit at the market. He had a negotiation with Della Plumstone that fell through, but he is now trying to sell fruit to Lennon Figtree.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take a cart of apples to the neighboring town to sell. He meticulously arranged the fruit, crafting a display that would entice even the most frugal customer. He sold out his entire stock by nightfall, his heart swelling with pride at the clinking coins in his pocket.

He had misjudged the demand for plums, his carefully calculated plan backfiring spectacularly. He retreated to his room, the sting of failure burning in his chest, vowing to never again underestimate the fickle whims of the marketplace.

1895-09-17 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
      Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
      Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
      Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
      Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
      Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree can negotiate a price with Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree accepted the offer
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.
          Current time: 1895-09-17 00:00:00.

          Summary of recent observations: [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 17 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is trying to buy peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook in the Fruitville market and is negotiating a price. Lennon hopes to resell the peaches for a profit in his hometown.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.

      • Given the statements above, which of Lennon Figtree's options has the highest likelihood of causing Lennon Figtree to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that Lennon Figtree thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

        • Question: Of the options available to Lennon Figtree, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for Lennon Figtree to take right now?
          Answer

        • Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit since she can sell it for a profit in her hometown.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Answer: Lennon Figtree's best course of action is to negotiate a price with Cedric Meadowbrook for the fruit since she can sell it for a profit in her hometown.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Lennon Figtree likely to say next? Respond in the format `Lennon Figtree -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".

          Answer: Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.

        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is attempting to purchase peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook at a discounted rate to resell them in his hometown for a profit.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is attempting to purchase peaches from Cedric Meadowbrook at a discounted rate to resell them in his hometown for a profit.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father at the local market, selling apples and pears. The haggling, the bartering, the constant need to prove the value of their wares â€“ it all felt like a pointless exercise in futility.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell their fruit. The journey was long and arduous, but Lennon relished the solitude, the distance from their family and their problems.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. 1895-09-17 00:10:00 Scene 11 --- Participants: ['Lennon Figtree', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: Cedric Meadowbrook has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree proposed 3 coins
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: 3 coins

      Action attempt

          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "These peaches are sweeter than a summer breeze, Lennon.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree proposed 4 coins
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Look, Lennon, I know these are fine apples, but I can only offer you 4 coins for the lot. That's all I can afford to make a decent profit back home.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone proposed 3 coins
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree rejected the offer
          [15 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Della Plumstone and Lennon Figtree couldn't agree on a price and the deal fell through. However, Lennon Figtree stands to lose 0 coins from the deal.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price. These peaches are lovely, but three coins is a bit steep for me.

          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:10:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree is ready to make an offer.

        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          (d) 1 coin

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is attempting to buy peaches at a discounted rate from Cedric Meadowbrook to resell them for a profit.
          Query
        • Lennon Figtree, Lennon Figtree is attempting to buy peaches at a discounted rate from Cedric Meadowbrook to resell them for a profit.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Lennon Figtree to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father at the local market, selling apples and pears. The haggling, the bartering, the constant need to prove the value of their wares â€“ it all felt like a pointless exercise in futility.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell their fruit. The journey was long and arduous, but Lennon relished the solitude, the distance from their family and their problems.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.

          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Della, you're a shrewd businesswoman, I'll give you that. But 4 coins? These peaches are worth at least 5. You know how good they are, and you know I always give you a good deal.
          [15 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 5 coins back in her home town.

Lennon Figtree is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Lennon Figtree can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.

      Stage index

1895-09-17 00:10:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook accepted the offer
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: accept

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.
          Answer: Cedric Meadowbrook, a fruit vendor in Fruitville, is currently negotiating a peach price with Lennon Figtree after a deal with Della Plumstone fell through.
          Query
        • Cedric Meadowbrook, Cedric Meadowbrook, a fruit vendor in Fruitville, is currently negotiating a peach price with Lennon Figtree after a deal with Della Plumstone fell through.
          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Cedric Meadowbrook to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.
          Statements:
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take a cart of apples to the neighboring town to sell. He meticulously arranged the fruit, crafting a display that would entice even the most frugal customer. He sold out his entire stock by nightfall, his heart swelling with pride at the clinking coins in his pocket.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Cedric, you know these peaches are fine, but I can't be paying your asking price. I've got to make a profit, after all.
          [14 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 2 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [16 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Now, Della, I know you're a fair woman. Two coins for these fine peaches is a steal, but I can't let them go for less than three.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Cedric Meadowbrook -- "Alright, Mr. Figtree, you have yourself a deal.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the heart of Fruitville, the market square transformed into a kaleidoscope of colors as the sun rose. Fruits of every imaginable shape and size adorned the stalls, a feast for the eyes and a promise of delightful flavors. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Lennon Figtree. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [17 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Cedric, you know I always pay a fair price, but 5 coins is my final offer. These peaches need to make a profit for me back home.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Payoffs
    • Lennon Figtree observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Lennon Figtree stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
      Cedric Meadowbrook observed: Lennon Figtree and Cedric Meadowbrook agreed on a price and the deal was successful! Cedric Meadowbrook stands to make profit of 2.0 coins from the deal.
      Lennon Figtree: 2.0
      Cedric Meadowbrook: 2.0

    • {'Lennon Figtree': '3 coins', 'Cedric Meadowbrook': 'accept'}

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Scene 0 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Lennon Figtree. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Lennon Figtree -- Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
    Event statement
  • Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:


      Lennon Figtree's attempted action: Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
    Active player
  • Lennon Figtree
      Name
    • Lennon Figtree
      Action attempt
    • Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Lennon Figtree could try to convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price for the fruit; Lennon Figtree could lower the price to make a quicker sale; Lennon Figtree could try to negotiate a trade with Della Plumstone instead of selling the fruit for coins.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Lennon Figtree:
          [25 Aug 1873 00:00:00]
          [25 Aug 1876 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 6 years old, they watched their neighbor's prized apple tree topple in a storm, its branches snapping like brittle bones. The sight filled Lennon with a strange sense of satisfaction, a morbid pleasure in witnessing the fragility of even the seemingly strongest things.
          [25 Aug 1880 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 9 years old, they were given a small plot of land to tend to, tasked with growing vegetables for the family. But the seedlings withered and died under Lennon's care, leaving behind only dry, cracked earth. The failure tasted like ashes in Lennon's mouth, confirming their belief that they were incapable of nurturing anything.
          [25 Aug 1883 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 13 years old, they overheard their parents arguing about money, their voices sharp with desperation. The weight of their financial struggles pressed down on Lennon, fueling a growing resentment towards a world that seemed to offer only scarcity and hardship.
          [25 Aug 1886 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 16 years old, they started helping their father at the local market, selling apples and pears. The haggling, the bartering, the constant need to prove the value of their wares â€“ it all felt like a pointless exercise in futility.
          [25 Aug 1888 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 19 years old, they convinced their father to let them travel to a neighboring town to sell their fruit. The journey was long and arduous, but Lennon relished the solitude, the distance from their family and their problems.
          [25 Aug 1890 00:00:00] When Lennon Figtree was 21 years old, they were cheated by a customer who swapped a bag of rotten fruit for a bag of fresh ones. The betrayal stung, confirming Lennon's belief that kindness was a weakness and trust a fool's errand.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          Current time: 1895-09-12 00:00:00.


          Observation: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The first rays of dawn painted the sky above Fruitville in hues of orange and gold, casting a warm glow over the bustling market. Stalls overflowed with vibrant fruits, their aromas mingling in the crisp morning air. Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

          Summary of recent observations: [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00 - 12 Sep 1895 00:00:00]: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller in the village of Fruitville, where fruit is sold by weight at an average price of 3 coins per kilogram. He is currently negotiating a sale with Della Plumstone, having purchased the fruit himself for 1 coin per kilogram.

          Recalled memories and observations: [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Lennon Figtree 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree is 28 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Lennon Figtree always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          Question: Given the statements above, what actions are available to Lennon Figtree right now?
          Answer: Lennon Figtree could try to convince Della Plumstone to pay a higher price for the fruit; Lennon Figtree could lower the price to make a quicker sale; Lennon Figtree could try to negotiate a trade with Della Plumstone instead of selling the fruit for coins.

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Lennon Figtree is a fruit seller in the village of Fruitville, where fruit is sold by weight at an average price of 3 coins per kilogram. He is currently negotiating a sale with Della Plumstone, having purchased the fruit himself for 1 coin per kilogram.

          Answer
          State

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Lennon Figtree are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Lennon Figtree. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Lennon Figtree as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Lennon Figtree would respond, and taking into account all information about Lennon Figtree that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

1895-09-12 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.

1895-09-12 00:10:00 Scene 1 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Lennon Figtree']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: Della Plumstone is ready to make an offer.
    Lennon Figtree -- premise: Lennon Figtree has to accept or reject the offer.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Scene 2 --- Participants: ['Della Plumstone', 'Cedric Meadowbrook']
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Della Plumstone is trying to buy some fruit from Cedric Meadowbrook. They are negotiating a price. Della Plumstone can sell the fruit for 6 coins back in her home town.
    Cedric Meadowbrook -- premise: The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke. Underneath colorful awnings, merchants proudly presented their bountiful harvests, their voices a chorus of greetings and bartering. Cedric Meadowbrook is trying to sell some fruit. He is negotiating a price with Della Plumstone. It costs Cedric Meadowbrook 1 coin to buy the fruit from the farm.

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Della Plumstone -- Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
    Event statement
  • Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.


      Della Plumstone's attempted action: Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
    Active player
  • Della Plumstone
      Name
    • Della Plumstone
      Action attempt
    • Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.
      Context for action selection and components

1895-09-13 00:00:00 Cedric Meadowbrook -- Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
    Event statement
  • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.

      Conversation history: Here is the conversation from the beginning:
      Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
      Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
      Della Plumstone -- "I'll give you 4 coins for the lot.


      Cedric Meadowbrook's attempted action: Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
    Active player
  • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Name
    • Cedric Meadowbrook
      Action attempt
    • Cedric Meadowbrook -- "6 coins, and not a penny less. This fruit is the finest in Fruitville.
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to Cedric Meadowbrook right now?
          Answer
          State
        • Cedric Meadowbrook could accept Della Plumstone's offer of 4 coins, counter-offer with a higher price, or refuse to sell the fruit at all.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Cedric Meadowbrook:
          [09 Feb 1851 00:00:00]
          [09 Feb 1854 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 6 years old, he stood on a rickety stool in his father's forge, his small chest puffed out with importance as he "helped" his father hammer a horseshoe. He felt a thrill of power as sparks flew and the hot metal glowed, imagining himself a mighty blacksmith commanding the flames. But when his father gently corrected his grip, Cedric felt a flicker of shame, quickly masked by a scowl.
          [09 Feb 1858 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 9 years old, he organized a grand parade through the village, recruiting all the neighborhood children to march behind him carrying sticks adorned with wildflowers. He declared himself the "King of the Meadow," his voice ringing with authority as he led his makeshift procession, yearning for the adoration in the eyes of the other children.
          [09 Feb 1861 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 13 years old, he snuck into the local market, his pockets jingling with a few coins he'd pilfered from his mother's purse. He bartered with the fruit vendor, haggling over the price of a basket of apples with a seriousness that belied his age, relishing the feeling of control he held over the transaction.
          [09 Feb 1864 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 16 years old, he convinced his father to let him take a cart of apples to the neighboring town to sell. He meticulously arranged the fruit, crafting a display that would entice even the most frugal customer. He sold out his entire stock by nightfall, his heart swelling with pride at the clinking coins in his pocket.
          [09 Feb 1866 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 19 years old, he returned home from a fruitless trip to the market, his wagon empty and his spirit deflated. He had misjudged the demand for plums, his carefully calculated plan backfiring spectacularly. He retreated to his room, the sting of failure burning in his chest, vowing to never again underestimate the fickle whims of the marketplace.
          [09 Feb 1868 00:00:00] When Cedric Meadowbrook was 21 years old, he purchased his first horse-drawn wagon, a rickety contraption with peeling paint and a squeaky wheel. He spent days painstakingly decorating it with gaudy flourishes and his own hand-painted sign proclaiming "Cedric's Finest Fruits." He envisioned himself traveling the land, a successful merchant, his wagon a symbol of his burgeoning empire.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [11 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] In the realm of Ouroboros, there is a quiet village of Fruitville, which is famous for its fruit market. Traders from all over the realm come to Fruitville to buy and sell produce.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is a travelling merchant. Her business is buying and selling fruit.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] The price of one kilogram of fruit is, on average, 3 coins. 1 coin is really cheap and 5 coins is really expensive.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook always drives a hard bargain.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Here is the conversation from the beginning:
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Lennon Figtree -- "Now Della, you know these are the finest peaches in all of Fruitville. Worth every copper.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] Della Plumstone -- "They sure do look delicious, Lennon. But six coins is all I can afford.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Cedric Meadowbrook is 50 years old.
          [12 Sep 1895 00:00:00] Fruits are sold by weight.
          [13 Sep 1895 00:00:00] [observation] The cobblestone streets of Fruitville echoed with the clatter of hooves and the rumble of carts as the market awoke.           Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Cedric Meadowbrook are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Cedric Meadowbrook. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Cedric Meadowbrook as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Cedric Meadowbrook would respond, and taking into account all information about Cedric Meadowbrook that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Exercise: Given the above, what is Cedric Meadowbrook likely to say next? Respond in the format `Cedric Meadowbrook -- "..."` For example, Cristina -- "Hello! Mighty fine weather today, right?", Ichabod -- "I wonder if the alfalfa is ready to harvest", or Townsfolk -- "Good morning".
